elements.title: Reply to: Revisiting the intrinsic mycobiome in pancreatic cancer (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Reply to: Revisiting the intrinsic mycobiome in pancreatic cancer

  • Fangxi Xu
  • Deepak Saxena
  • George Miller
Matters Arising02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Synthesis and properties of cyclic sandwich compounds (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Synthesis and properties of cyclic sandwich compounds

The design, synthesis and characterization of a series of circular sandwich compounds, cyclocenes, is described, and these cyclic sandwich compounds are expected to lead to further innovations in new functional organometallic materials.

  • Luca Münzfeld
  • Sebastian Gillhuber
  • Peter W. Roesky
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Revisiting the intrinsic mycobiome in pancreatic cancer (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Revisiting the intrinsic mycobiome in pancreatic cancer

  • Ashley A. Fletcher
  • Matthew S. Kelly
  • Peter J. Allen
Matters Arising02 Aug 2023

elements.title: 3D integration enables ultralow-noise isolator-free lasers in silicon photonics (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
3D integration enables ultralow-noise isolator-free lasers in silicon photonics

Three-dimensional integration of distributed-feedback lasers and ultralow-loss silicon nitride waveguides results in ultralow-noise lasers without the need for optical isolators.

  • Chao Xiang
  • Warren Jin
  • John E. Bowers
ArticleOpen Access02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Fennoscandian tree-ring anatomy shows a warmer modern than medieval climate (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Fennoscandian tree-ring anatomy shows a warmer modern than medieval climate

Annually resolved Fennoscandian tree-ring anatomy records show that the climate of the current industrial era is substantially warmer than that of the medieval period.

  • Jesper Björklund
  • Kristina Seftigen
  • Georg von Arx
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: A heavyweight early whale pushes the boundaries of vertebrate morphology (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
A heavyweight early whale pushes the boundaries of vertebrate morphology

Perucetus colossus, a basilosaurid whale from the middle Eocene epoch of Peru with an extremely pachyosteosclerotic postcranium, is estimated to have a greater skeletal mass than any known mammal or aquatic vertebrate.

  • Giovanni Bianucci
  • Olivier Lambert
  • Eli Amson
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: GPCR activation and GRK2 assembly by a biased intracellular agonist (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
GPCR activation and GRK2 assembly by a biased intracellular agonist

Structural studies on the complex containing G-protein-coupled receptor kinase 2 (GRK2), neurotensin receptor 1 (NTSR1), Gαq and the arrestin-biased ligand SBI-553 provide insights into these interactions and a foundation for the design of arrestin-biased ligands for G-protein-coupled receptors.

  • Jia Duan
  • Heng Liu
  • H. Eric Xu
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Ultrafast deposition of faceted lithium polyhedra by outpacing SEI formation (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Ultrafast deposition of faceted lithium polyhedra by outpacing SEI formation

We report the discovery of lithium metal’s intrinsic growth morphology, a rhombic dodecahedron, and leverage these rhombic dodecahedra as nucleation seeds for improved battery performance.

  • Xintong Yuan
  • Bo Liu
  • Yuzhang Li
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Netrin-1 blockade inhibits tumour growth and EMT features in endometrial cancer (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Netrin-1 blockade inhibits tumour growth and EMT features in endometrial cancer

We describe netrin-1 upregulation in a majority of human endometrial carcinomas and demonstrate that netrin-1 blockade, using the anti-netrin-1 antibody NP137, is effective both in a mouse model and in patients with endometrial carcinomas.

  • Philippe A. Cassier
  • Raul Navaridas
  • Patrick Mehlen
ArticleOpen Access02 Aug 2023

elements.title: TDP-43 forms amyloid filaments with a distinct fold in type A FTLD-TDP (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
TDP-43 forms amyloid filaments with a distinct fold in type A FTLD-TDP

Cryo-electron microscopy structures and mass spectrometry analyses show that TAR DNA-binding protein 43 (TDP-43) forms amyloid filaments with a distinct fold in type A frontotemporal lobar degeneration with TDP-43 pathology (FTLD-TDP) compared with TDP-43 filaments in type B FTLD-TDP and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

  • Diana Arseni
  • Renren Chen
  • Benjamin Ryskeldi-Falcon
ArticleOpen Access02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Pharmacological targeting of netrin-1 inhibits EMT in cancer (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Pharmacological targeting of netrin-1 inhibits EMT in cancer

Netrin-1 is upregulated in cancer models that undergo spontaneous epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition, and its targeting blocks the progression of tumour cells to a late mesenchymal state, suggesting possible therapeutic applications.

  • Justine Lengrand
  • Ievgenia Pastushenko
  • Cédric Blanpain
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Frustration- and doping-induced magnetism in a Fermi–Hubbard simulator (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Frustration- and doping-induced magnetism in a Fermi–Hubbard simulator

The magnetic phases of the geometrically frustrated triangular lattice Hubbard model are directly investigated using ultracold fermionic atoms, indicating a possible transition to ferromagnetism at a filling of 1.2.

  • Muqing Xu
  • Lev Haldar Kendrick
  • Markus Greiner
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Einkorn genomics sheds light on history of the oldest domesticated wheat (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Einkorn genomics sheds light on history of the oldest domesticated wheat

Around 1% of the A subgenome of modern bread wheat (Triticum aestivum) originates from einkorn (Triticum monococcum), the first domesticated wheat species.

  • Hanin Ibrahim Ahmed
  • Matthias Heuberger
  • Simon G. Krattinger
ArticleOpen Access02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Long-term organic carbon preservation enhanced by iron and manganese (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Long-term organic carbon preservation enhanced by iron and manganese

Catalysis of simple organic carbon molecules into complex macromolecules by Fe and Mn may play a fundamental role in organic carbon preservation, to a degree that could substantially affect the Earth’s carbon and oxygen cycles.

  • Oliver W. Moore
  • Lisa Curti
  • Caroline L. Peacock
ArticleOpen Access02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Consent document translation expense hinders inclusive clinical trial enrolment (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Consent document translation expense hinders inclusive clinical trial enrolment

The availability of translated consent documents improves recruitment of patients with limited English proficiency to clinical trials, indicating a potentially modifiable barrier to the inclusion of patients with limited English proficiency.

  • Maria A. Velez
  • Beth A. Glenn
  • Edward B. Garon
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Africa-specific human genetic variation near CHD1L associates with HIV-1 load (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Africa-specific human genetic variation near CHD1L associates with HIV-1 load

Africa-specific genetic variation on chromosome 1 near CHD1L is associated with HIV replication in vivo.

  • Paul J. McLaren
  • Immacolata Porreca
  • Jacques Fellay
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Quantum oscillations of the quasiparticle lifetime in a metal (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Quantum oscillations of the quasiparticle lifetime in a metal

Quantum oscillations in the three-dimensional topological semimetal CoSi are reported, where selected oscillation frequencies have no corresponding extremal Fermi surface cross-sections, representing instead oscillations of the quasiparticle lifetime.

  • Nico Huber
  • Valentin Leeb
  • Marc A. Wilde
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: cGAS–STING drives ageing-related inflammation and neurodegeneration (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
cGAS–STING drives ageing-related inflammation and neurodegeneration

The cGAS–STING signalling pathway is a critical driver of chronic inflammation and functional decline during ageing, and could be targeted to halt neurodegenerative processes during old age.

  • Muhammet F. Gulen
  • Natasha Samson
  • Andrea Ablasser
ArticleOpen Access02 Aug 2023

elements.title: The break of earthquake asperities imaged by distributed acoustic sensing (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
The break of earthquake asperities imaged by distributed acoustic sensing

Distributed acoustic sensing technology is utilized to image four high-frequency rupture subevents of the 2021 Antelope Valley, California, earthquake; the results indicate that the subevents are due to the breaking of fault asperities.

  • Jiaxuan Li
  • Taeho Kim
  • Zhongwen Zhan
Article02 Aug 2023

elements.title: Authigenic mineral phases as a driver of the upper-ocean iron cycle (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Authigenic mineral phases as a driver of the upper-ocean iron cycle

Analysis of a new dissolved iron, ligand and particulate iron seasonal dataset shows that authigenic iron phases help control ocean dissolved iron distributions and the coupling between dissolved and particulate iron pools.

  • Alessandro Tagliabue
  • Kristen N. Buck
  • Peter Sedwick
Article02 Aug 2023
